Hey Hack, there are some great deals to be had on new Evinrudes since this is the last year BRP is making outboards. BRP has to honor all warranties and they are required to continue producing replacement parts. Â It may be a bit more than a good used motor but you can buy new and get it at pretty darn good price.

Google is your friend. Search the make, model, year and hp class thoroughly prior to buying anything. Opinions on here are just that, opinions. Do your homework!

My only experience with four strokes is with the Yamaha's that I've had over the years and I truly believe that they are the most reliable outboard available currently. That by far is the most important thing to me. knowing that I'm getting back!
Don't overlook Tohatsu. They made many of the others small to medium 4 strokes.

I quite agree. However Google is quite the rabbit hole. Then again asking this question here on a forum is the same thing. Everybody has opinions. Â The marine version of Ford versus Chevy versus dodge.Â I will have to pick and choose where I side. (And Â lwith the written word itâ€™s hard to tell sometimes or somebodyâ€™s coming across. Depended on the year and the engine, I put on a fair number of hours per season. the most I've put on an engine in a season was 185 hrs. and the most that I've put on a single engine over a four years was 650 hrs. I also know most of the people who had purchased my boats & engine and the only one that ever blew up was an Evinrude from 2004!

Iâ€™m running a 22 year old Yamaha...thing starts like itâ€™s new, doesnâ€™t really put out much smoke for a two stroke and hasnâ€™t given me a single issue and I definitely run it close to 100 hours a year. I also have an 88 suzuki that runs and has been abused horribly over the years lol. The original oil pump still works I donâ€™t even have to run mix in it. previous owner told me the only thing ever done on it was the valve cover gasket. Aside from that itâ€™s oem. I changed the impeller in it when I bought it. Thatâ€™s it.

So far I love my Evinrude - so it was disappointing to see the BRP is ending the line (I am on 2.5 seasons with a G1 135HO).Â  They have sold it entirely to Mercury - so it will be interesting to see what happens.Â  But perhaps you can get a great deal on a clearance Evinrude?
Yamaha, Suzuki, Honda.

The honest truth is that among today's 50 hp to 75 hp engines there really isn't a bad choice, they're all very close in terms of fuel efficiency and overall reliability. Go to each manufacturer's website and you can read the specifics on each ... there are some minor weight and feature differences that might swing you one way or another. But the biggest difference is most likely going to come down to the dealer you buy it from ... some may offer incentives that the others don't, or be more convenient for service etc.  Just for clarity, BRP did not sell Evinrude to Mercury, or to anyone else. Evinrude is discontinued, meaning BRP still owns the name and such but will no longer build the engines.
You are correct - I misread the news article.

Also check with the marinas/dealers you prefer. They may have some coming in from folks upgrading. May helpÂ a sales person selling when they can tell their prospect they can sell theirÂ old one.

I'm in a similar situation as OP here... Looking to re power and have found tohatsu to be very well priced. I inquired about a 50 hp console model 4 stroke and pricing was $6071 brand new. I was about to pull the trigger on a 2013 I came across on Kijiji but the guy wanted $4500 for it, (probably would have haggled him down) and he hadn't had it running since 2016 when he purchased it from someone else. For $1500~ I don't want someone else's issues if there are any, plus there's a brand new warranty.
A lot of older four stroke mercuryÂ  are Yamaha engine with mercury bottom end. I have a 12 year old 90 mercury 4 stroke with 1500 hr on it. Have never had a problemÂ  yet.
Need to look at dealer support all engines are.pretty.decent butnif you need to drive 3 hours for service not a great choice pick one thats close to you and.most places you go

For what it's worth, I've had 4 outboards in the last 35 years....one Suzuki, one Johnson, and two Yamahas (4 strokes)....in that order. Suzuki was great, Both Yams great. The Johnson was a huge POS....couldn't wait to get rid of it.
What year was the Johnny? 2 stroke on that one?

Hack....I'm guessing 1988. Regardless of tuning, filter changes, etc. it would commonly stall after slowing down from near wide open. When this happened, about 50% of the time, it would flood trying to restart it. This then required unhooking gas line from engine, and trying to restart with choke wide open. Mechanics always concluded there was nothing wrong with it.

Iâ€™m gonna also chime in and tell you that my 88 suzuki still goes, Â my 94 Johnson is dead with electrical issues that couldnâ€™t be fixed without buying a new control module every year the thing kept frying itself. The 98 Yamaha runs like a top. The 2002 Mercury is running but itâ€™s had electrical problems as well that we were able to fix.

Thanks again guys. I havenâ€™t got any new pricing yet. Every day I search Kijiji or FB marketplace for used. I was hoping to find a 90â€™s or early 2000â€™s OMC 60 or 70 as I had always heard they were solid...but perhaps not. Finding 70 Yamahas is like finding hens teeth.
